title: Galaxies, auroras and a cosmic bat: Southern Sky astrophotography exhibition 2024 – in pictures
description: The Southern Sky Astrophotography 2024 exhibition displays the top entries from the 20th David Malin awards for Australian astronomers and photographers. The images are on display at the Sydney observatory until 1 February Continue reading...
author: Guardian Staff
excerpt: The Southern Sky Astrophotography 2024 exhibition displays the top entries from the 20th David Malin awards for Australian astronomers and photographers. The images are on display at the Sydney observatory until 1 February
text: Overall winner and winner, wide-field category: The Region Around Rho Ophiuchi by Jarrod KohThe Rho Ophiuchi cloud complex in constellation Ophiuchus. This image is a mosaic of 15 panels with a total exposure time of 72 hours. Winner, nightscapes category: Skógafoss Disco by Alex van HarmelenMulticolour auroral rays illuminate the sky on a night of high activity near the famous Skógafoss waterfall. Honourable mention, deep sky category: Andromeda Galaxy by Michelle BennettThe Andromeda galaxy is the nearest large spiral galaxy to our Milky Way at 2.5m light years away. It is the most distant object visible to the naked eye. Honourable mention, deep sky category: IC 2944 Region and Supernova Remnant by Andy CampbellThe IC 2944 nebula in Centaurus surrounds the bright star Lambda Centauri. The wispy remains of a rarely captured exploded star, or supernova, are at the top left. Honourable mention, solar system category: Aristarchus Plateau by Stefan BudaThe bright crater Aristarchus lies on a shallow volcanic plateau in the Oceanus Procellarum on the moon. Vallis Schröteri, a lava channel, snakes across the plateau for 185 km. Lunar faults, wrinkle ridges and grey rays of ejecta complete this lunar landscape. Winner, junior category: The Rainbow Prawn by Lachlan WilsonThe Prawn Nebula, IC 4628, in the tail of constellation Scorpius, is a place of star birth. Honourable mention, solar system category: Tethys Disappearing by Andy CaselyThe incomparable Saturn on 24 September 2023. Here Tethys, Saturn’s fifth-largest moon, is about to disappear. Honourable mention, wide-field category: Large Magellanic Cloud – RGBHa by Rodney WattersThe Large Magellanic Cloud, a small companion galaxy to the Milky Way, is 160,000 light years away. Glowing red hydrogen gas surrounds hot young stars. Blue-white stars trace a subtle spiral structure. Honourable mention, nightscapes category: Gibson Steps Southern Lights by Baillie FarleyThe solar wind is channelled by Earth’s magnetic field towards the polar regions, causing the northern and southern lights. On nights of very high activity they are seen far from the poles, such as here on the Victorian coast. Winner, working with light in the night category: Kaleidoscope by Ed HurstHaving caught the colourful lights of Vivid Sydney, further exposures captured the setting star trails. Honourable mention, nightscapes category: Aurora Falls above the Falls by Alex van HarmelenThe northern lights, or aurora borealis, over Skógafoss waterfall in Iceland. Auroras result from solar wind particles exciting oxygen, nitrogen and sometimes hydrogen in Earth’s atmosphere. Honourable mention, deep sky category: Big Things are Afoot by Paul MontagueLooking towards the core of the Milky Way, our view is blocked by clouds of dust and gas like IC 4685 in constellation Sagittarius. Honourable mention, working with light in the night category: Nature’s Own Light Show by Baillie FarleyA 360-degree panorama of the southern lights from the Victorian coast. The aurora is to the south (centre) and a double stable auroral red (SAR) arc is to the north (left and right). Winner, solar system category:Detachment by Andy CaseyThis double arc prominence erupting from the Sun’s surface reaches 225,000km into space. Honourable mention, working with light in the night category: Archway Glow by Luke TscharkeMillions of Milky Way stars merge into patches of white light and fade into the night glow of Hobart. Dead trees mirror the dark branching dust lanes of the galaxy. Winner, deep sky category: The Cosmic Bat Nebula – LDN 4 by Jarrod KohLynds’ Dark Nebula 43 in constellation Ophiuchus is a cloud of hydrogen gas and carbon dust resembling a cosmic bat.
